Amanita phalloides. I recognized it from the thumbnail. Like the woman in the story I too missed the volva at the base of the mushroom, but unlike her I didn't put the mushroom in my mouth. I puzzled over the ID for sometime, until I noticed a scrap of tissue at the base. The ground was hard (a neighbor's front yard) and the volva was much smaller than typical--squeezed tightly around the base of the stem. Now that I know A. phalloides by sight and scent, I'll never miss it again.

There are several common genera of mushrooms with a volva: Amanita, Volvariella, and Phallus. Amanita is more common in temperate zones, has only a few edibles, but some of the most deadly mushroom species in the world. Easy to identify to genus, and therefore easy to avoid. Volvariella is more common in the tropics, and has many edibles, V. volvacea being widely cultivated and consumed. It's even available canned in many US supermarkets as straw mushroom. Any toxic members of Volvariella won't do much more than give you a belly ache. There has been a problem in California as Vietnamese immigrants collect Amanita thinking that they've collected Volvariella with very unpleasant results. Finally, there's no way anyone will mistake a Phallus for something else. Fun project, Google Phallus impudictus.

Figuring out what to eat is so much easier than people think. Rub a small part of it inside your elbow. Reaction? Stop. No reaction? Chew a tiny peice in your mouth --don't swallow, spit. Reaction? Stop. No reaction? Repeat the last step but swallow.

Wait 24 hours to eat anything else after each step and don't eat anything 8 hours prior to testing. Also note that just because the berry is edible, doesn't mean that the leaf/stem/flower/root is ok. Always prepare it how you intend to eat it. Last couple steps are the same as the third, but with larger portions. I would recommend anyone eating wild mushrooms to do this before consuming them. Mushrooms are notoriously hard to identify, and some species are only edible after cooking.

The button Amanita being mistaken for a puffball is a well known mistake, but all puffballs must be cut in half to inspect before consumption anyway, and that reveals it's actually an Amanita, as their structure is entirely different. It's silly to think scientist can eradicate this fungus from California after all these years. People just need to actually do due diligence. I know because I forage and consume or otherwise use probably two dozen species of mushroom. I'm not an expert, but I know enough to think I know something I don't and make a mistake. However, I learned by always checking and rechecking to make certain I've not slipped into a confused deadly mistake. It can and likely will happen if people don't carefully check for toxic lookalikes, or bother with carefully inspecting each individual mushroom harvested from a place of plenty. Spore printing can often be key, and should always be practiced if there's any doubt. Until doubt has been eliminated methodically, the mushroom must not be consumed. It's like handling firearms, but far less dangerous. Don't take chances, don't assume you know it's unloaded or loaded, check it out methodically. It can be tricky bussiness, especially if you travel to a an unfamiliar geographic region, with unfamiliar toxic look alikes. Always give them to somebody you don't particularly care for first. Or just be aware when in an unfamiliar geographic region.
Stay away from gilled mushrooms stick to polypore bracket mushrooms

I am a mushroom forager. If you can’t recognize a potential death cap, you are beyond a novice and should not be eating your finds. Foraging is FINE and FUN, just triple-check what you find, and don’t eat anything you don’t 100% know what it is. There are MANY delicious species that have no/limited look-a-likes. Death caps (or gilled mushrooms in general) are much harder to identify.

Death caps don’t kill everything. Chipmunks (and possible squirrels) seem to enjoy eating them without harm. At least, the ones in my yard are constantly eating them. Also, mushrooms are signs of a healthy yard/forest. They have a symbiotic relationship with trees and plants that helps them absorb nutrients that can’t get on their own, as suggested by the video. Many mushrooms help beak down the wood of dead and dying trees. Just don’t eat a mushroom because it looks good.  Go with an experienced mushroom hunter. Some deadly mushrooms can inly be differentiated from edible ones by spore print. Don’t take a chance: never eat a mushroom you didn’t buy.

Fun Fact- Although the some species of the same Fungus (like A.muscarea, A.phalloides)(commonly called toadstools) are poisonous, others like Amanita muscaria are a source of powerful drugs and hallucinogens like LSD.

The video says she missed the volva, but that isn't what happened here at all. She mistook pre-emergence deathcaps, deathcaps still inside the volva, for puff balls. FWIW, puffballs are considered a member of the "foolproof four."

The moral of the story is cut your puffballs in half and inspect every single one for homogeneity. True puffballs will be uniform. Pre-emergence Amanita will have differences in tissue. Death Caps are definitely something to respect, but even a modicum of caution prevents these sorts of mix-ups.

I immediately recognized that mushroom, in Germany we call them 'Grüner Knollenblätterpilz'. They are I believe the most toxic of their order but not the deadliest. That's because they don't look similar to any edible mushroom, at least that's true for my region in Germany.

Their white brother is way more dangerous because it looks nearly exactly like a champignon when both mushrooms are sprouting freshly out of the ground. Plus both mushrooms grow can grow in the same spots, open grassy areas in and around forests. Which is why I collect lots of mushrooms but have never gone looking for wild champignons, I am better at discerning what kind of mushroom I am picking than most people but some things are just not worth the risk, so I stick to what I know to be safe.

Europe here and I collect mushrooms, too. But I only collect boletes ('tube mushrooms') where you have to be lucky to find the single poisonous one. And there are some others that just taste badly (bitter bolete). 

Apart from boletes I collect chanterelles ONLY ('lamella mushrooms'). Our native death cap and other amanitae are 'lamella mushrooms'. They do not kill you if you touch them but I still avoid them. 

As I do not collect any lemalla mushrooms apart from chanterelles I avoid any risk.
There are some boletes we should avoid here due to the disaster at Chernobyl nuclear power plant. There are certain kinds that enrich caesium-137 like the bay bolete so they are still quite radio active. Caesium-137 has a half life time of about 30 years so there's still half the amount left in our environment.

⚠️ The title is technically wrong. The mushroom's poison only becomes poison once it enters the liver, because it is the liver that changes it to a poison. It is a very unique situation. It isn't poison until it is converted by the liver. Thankfully because of this, there is a plant seed that allows the poison to go into the kidneys instead. Protecting the liver from making this fatal mistake. It is the milk thistle seed (Silybum marianum). You do need to take a fairly good amount from what I hear. I could be mistaken on this. But is good to know if so. S. Todd Mitchell of Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif., and his team have treated more than 60 patients suffering from amatoxin poisonings. Every patient who still had intact kidney function and was started on the drug within 96 hours of eating mushrooms has lived. Only a few patients sought treatment later and did not survive so you have hurry obviously. Hope this helps anyone out there. This is information I researched, I am not a physician. I only am here to give people insight into the truth of the matter. Do your own research please.

You don't just walk into the forest and assume that every mushroom is edible (= not poisonous). And just because the death cap is lethal to humans does not mean that we have the right to get rid of and permanently destroy it. Even toxic fungi (to us humans toxic, other animals are immune to some toxins and therefore some of these poisonous fungi are a food source for them) have the right to live. Maybe, instead of teaching our children French, we should teach them about nature: Why you shouldn't swim in a river, why you shouldn't climb mountains unprepared - and which mushrooms are p o i s o n o u s. Oh, and before you do anything in nature (or in general) inform yourself thoroughly and not just assume things.
Do not destroy them, they cost lives, but due to ignorance. Through ignorance, we could destroy the trees and thus the forest.

Fun fact: Death caps are completely harmless for many animals such as mice and rats.

It depends on how the liver is connected to the guts.
At humans the intake is after the liver's enzyme release, so the liver poisons itself with a product it produced out of the deathcap venom.

If you would change the order of the liver's intake and exhaust, the deathcap would be harmless (as it is to mice and rats)

Never EVER try to identify mushrooms purely based on their appearances.

Two completely different mushroom species can look identical in certain circumstances, and two individual mushrooms of a single species can look entirely different from each other, as well.

Identifying mushrooms is extremely difficult when compared to plants and animals.

Many people, even those with scientific backgrounds, assume basic dichotomous keys work pretty much the same for all life forms, but that’s just not the case with fungi.

The most definitive characteristic is a spore print, but you need to collect other information as well in order to identify it properly, unless you’re just trying to rule out inedible species.

The most reliable method we have right now for identification in a lab is the use of a high-powered microscope (*nothing you would have at home*).

Genetic testing isn’t even a reliable indicator yet because we don’t have very many species’ genetic information in databases yet.

There are A LOT of species of fungi, so even trying to sequence the most common types is a massive undertaking.

Ingesting one death cap

 mushroom is enough to kill a healthy adult. All parts of the mushroom are poisonous; cooking or peeling does not make the mushroom safe to eat.

How deadly are death cap mushrooms? Between 2010 and 2015, five people died in California and 57 became sick after eating the unassuming greenish mushrooms, according to the California Poison Control System. One mushroom cap is enough to kill a human being, and they're also poisonous to dogs.

Amanita phalloides /æməˈnaɪtə fəˈlɔɪdiːz/, commonly known as the death cap, is a deadly poisonous basidiomycete fungus, one of many in the genus Amanita. Widely distributed across Europe, but now sprouting in other parts of the world, A. phalloides forms ectomycorrhizas with various broadleaved trees.

What is the deadliest fungi in the world?

Amanita phalloides

The world's most poisonous mushroom,Amanita phalloides, is growing in BC. ABSTRACT: Amatoxins in Amanita phalloides, commonly known as the death cap mushroom, are responsible for 90% of the world's mushroom-related fatalities.

You forgot to mention that you can live if you eat one. The common wild mushroom, Amanita phalloides, is known as the "death cap" for a good reason. It takes only a handful of this widely distributed fungus to kill an adult, less to kill a child. Standard medical treatment - activated charcoal - is not particularly effective. Amanita phalloides mushroom ingestion proves fatal in about half of the cases. Twenty years ago, pilot studies showed that silymarin [milk thistle extract] treatment substantially reduced amanita-poisoning deaths in animals fed the mushroom. Subsequently, several human studies were launched. In one German hospital test, 60 consecutive people with amanita poisoning were given intravenous silymarin [milk thistle extract]. None died. With the rise of the modem pharmaceutical industry, U.S. research of herbal medicines declined considerably. Fortunately, this did not happen in Germany, where in 1949, scientists noticed that milk thistle seemed to protect animal livers from poisoning with highly toxic carbon tetrachloride. In 1968, scientists isolated the three specific liver-protective molecules in milk thistle - silibinin, silidianin, and silicristin - now known collectively as silymarin [milk thistle extract]. From what David Hoffmann, clinical herbalist, says is that the United States is the only ones that do not have it in their official pharmacopeia.

These mushrooms have been killing folks for some time, the recent increase [2016] has since dialed back a lot.
Climate change is real, and seeing 'unprecedented' flushes of plants/mushrooms/bugs is a sign of changing conditions.
Absence of plants/fungus/bugs is a bad sign, too.
When things change in the forest, you gotta ask about the nature of the change, and not waste time raking the forest floor.
Picking mushrooms before they throw spores is a waste of time and achieves nothing! Plus it exposes people to toxins.
The mycelium in the ground is completely unaffected by picking, and mycelium is the mushrooms 'roots'.
And mycelium is constantly spreading outward, so you have that.
If you wipe out mycelium, the forest dies.
Plants and fungus have an unbreakable symbiotic relationship.
Now do an article on the Northern California mushrooms that are deadly ONLY if you drink alcohol...I dare ya!

BTW, crying about the toxicity of these mushrooms "why do they need to be so deadly?" is specious; the chemicals in the body of a mushroom aren't toxic to all species.
The amount of zinc or iron in human blood is enough to kill most plants. Are we a 'toxic threat' to our houseplants? Why do we need to be so deadly to ferns?

here in Germany, we've developed a very simple, basic rule when it comes to mushrooms:

If it's a mushroom with gills - make sure you're 100% certain it's the kind of mushroom you want to have to eat, as most of them are toxic or even lethal.
if it's a mushroom with tubulars - as long as it's not red, it won't kill you. It might not taste that good, you may see some strange things or feel sick in the worst case, but you'll survive...or enjoy a delicious meal.

in the end, if you're unsure: Ask an expert!

The first rule of mushroom hunting has always been, KNOW how to identify and avoid deadly amanita mushrooms. Or only harvest what you absolutely know, that cannot be confused with amanitas. So I find it disingenuous that the presenter on this video suggests picking all the amanitas to protect people. One mushroom makes billions of spores that may remain in the ground for decades. It's pretty disturbing to realize that organisms (like these fungi) are being spread into foreign areas by humans (either accidentally or intentionally) so frequently that it's impossible to calculate the impact of their introduction upon the environment. (Pathogenic organisms, like the Human Influenza Virus Type A, can spread with staggering speed around the world.)

In Western Australia there are 'Magic Mushrooms' ( Psilocybe Subaeruginosa ), that were brought here sometime in the 1980s (from south-eastern asia) and have since spread out over hundreds of square kilometers. They contain several potent psychedelic drugs that can give users: euphoria, pleasurable sensory effects, fascinating hallucinations & powerful spirtual experiences. (They are - of course - illegal). The town of Balingup (in South-Western Australia) has actually become quite infamous because of this particular fungus, drawing aficionados from all 'round the world.

For America it is an invasive specie, in Europe it it's native, it's quite widespread. There is also white amanita, looks the same, but all white, just as deadly. When there is nothing to write about in late summer or early autumn, newspapers write about people who died from mushroom poisoning. Funnily enough, you can deliberately poison people with this mushroom just because it tastes very edible.

Taste is not a good indicator for how safe a mushroom is. It only works with boletes, because the only one that's really bitter is not edible, but it's also not poisonous, it's just nasty to the taste. Russulas are quite bitter, but they are edible.

There are a some edible mushrooms that are very distinct. It's better to collect only those than to drop dead but collect more. I also recommended to study what poisonous mushrooms grow in your region just to avoid them. If you doubt a mushroom, don't take it.

I live on a U.S. territory.. It's a island called Saipan in the CNMI.. So everything was easy to go around etc. It wasn't a big island as hawaii or something.. its a really really small island.. its like 1% in size comparison to new york city. but anyhoo...i was going to the jungle.. i i could smell this odor as i follow the smell.. i found this mushroom. i was like wow.. this the most nicest and biggest mushroom ive ever seen. whats cool is that it had a net around it. so i thought some has hide and planted this. i was wondering if someone plant it.. why is it all the way here?? is it illegal? i thought someone planted it because it had a net around it. until i got home. told my moma about it etc.. so my mom told me to take it.. so i did. i grab a plastic back and head out again. i grab it of the ground and god.. the smell was so bad a soft smell texture.. but deadly you know? so as i grabbed it.. i notice the mushroom growed its net its self.. show my mom it and she said its poisen and we cant eat it. i mean i know we cant. it had a bad smell. so anyways. i left it out.. didnt thought of bringing it back. later we were looking for my puppy as its time to fee them.. later not we cant find it. I look under the car and it was soo ill.. it was weak.. he couldnt even stand up. he struggled.. he was a perfect healthy puppy in the morning until after i got the mushroom.. his acting up. i was like.. is this a magical mush? all of a sudden it hit me! i was like NOO! did he ate the mushroom. so i ran and check the pasitc bag. found out the mushroom was into pieces.. and other animal around it. they seem to be eating it too but no other was dying but the puppy. so at that moment.. i knew the mushroom was poisen and my puppy ate it..

The reason Death Caps are so toxic is actually very simple. Death caps tend to grow specifically around the bases of tree root crowns the radius of a trees root system closest to the surface. This is also coincidentally where Truffles also tend grow. And in europe Wild boar ran rampant across europe, and they gorge themselves on truffles.There have been a few theories that state that the truffle and the Death cap coexist in a sort of confederate like symbiosis, that over time death caps evolved to propigate around truffles, and truffles evolved to thrive around death caps, and the more deadly the death cap the more fruitful the truffles around it. the benefit to the death cap is that when a pig digs up the soil it gives the death cap filaments access to deeper tree roots, while the pig then ingests the death cap, which have a very desirable flavor, and hours later the pig dies eliminating it as a future threat while secondarily spreading the death cap spores to other tree crowns directly where other truffles are.

I'm annoyed enough to give a thumbs down. There are a lot of things in nature which may attack you. But the Amanita Phalloides does not behave like that. Just don't eat it. And it really is not THAT close in lookalike to edible mushrooms. The closely related white death angel looks way more close to several edible and well tasting species (which is a good reason to avoid them). The beautiful deadly death cap resembles some edible as tasty specimen in Europe, which are of the same hue in colour, but look different at the stem (a lot different). I really like to search mushrooms, and occasionally I try new edible species. But not before I am really sure what it is. And it is absolutely helpful to know the more serious toxic ones. Don't go for mushrooms anywhere in the world without knowing the death cap, the white angel, the also rather toxic fluorescent green/yellow related, the fly amanita (in particular if you search  for caesers mushrooms), the panthers cap (again there are edible species around, which look quite similar). If you look for boletus species, you better should know the few toxic ones, in particular the Satans bolete (at least that's not very toxic). You may also think about toxic variants of the shaggy parasol (some can eat them), and be careful. And not to forget: There are quite some more deadly toxic things in the forest... Not so closely resembling edible ones. Just realize: You are not sure if it is the known good one, looks a bit strange? DON'T EAT IT!!!! The same with plants, fruits, whatever... We can eat way more things than most of the other species on earth. But there are enough deadly poisons out there, not every plant / mushroom wants to be eaten...

Interestingly, milk thistle seed has historically been given to people that ingested amanita, a toxic mushroom. The seeds contain the highest concentrations of the active compound, silymarin. Silymarin is an antioxidant that reduces free radical production and oxidative damage. It may also inhibit the binding of toxins to the liver. In animals, silymarin reduces liver injury caused by acetaminophen and has been shown to have positive effects on alcoholic liver disease, hepatitis and toxin-induced liver problems. To keep the amatoxins from causing damage silymarin would have to protect the liver while the kidneys eliminated the poison. Silibinin, a drug derived from the plant milk thistle, Silybum marianum, when administered intravenously, the compound sits on and blocks the receptors that bring amatoxin into the liver, thus corralling the amatoxins into the blood stream so the kidneys can expel them faster. The kidneys can continue to function only if the victim stays hydrated.

S. Todd Mitchell of Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif., and his team have treated more than 60 patients suffering from amatoxin poisonings. Every patient who still had intact kidney function and was started on the drug within 96 hours of eating mushrooms has lived. Only a few patients sought treatment later and did not survive.

That is an interesting question proposed in the video about what the point of the poison is. Fast-acting poison in nature makes sense: it defends the organism and/or the collective. But a poison that takes days to take effect, produced by a non-predatory creature is more of a mystery.

Only thing I can think of is that the population of animals that would eat it slowly start to dwindle, playing on the evolution of other animals such that the ones that don't eat the mushroom survive. Even then, sounds pretty hit-or-miss, especially since it is not guaranteed to kill.

Unfortunately, in many countries doctors miss the signs, and hospitals have no means to treat amanita mushroom poisonings. But it is possible:
Physicians have had success in treatment of amatoxin poisoning using "anti-hepatotoxic" compounds from the milk thistle, Silybum marianum. A crude extract of flavolignans from S. marianum seeds, called silymarin (trade name Legalon)
has proven useful in amatoxin poisoning cases. In a trial of one of the
flavolignans silybin, in 60 patients poisoned by amatoxin-containing Amanita species, there were no deaths. (see Der Marderosian & Liberti 1988 and Foster 1991 for a summary of this work) (Wikepedia).

Given how long it takes for the toxin to take effect, I suspect the death cap's poisonous nature is merely incidental and not meant for defense. It could easily be the case that the toxic substance serves some completely unrelated function for the mushroom, but which just happens to have a slow-acting poisonous effect on animals. It's caused mostly by unawareness, and mistaking them for Macrolepiota procera, which is less common, but tastes amazing. All in all, if you go mushroom picking, make sure you know what you are doing.

Aren't you demonising an otherwise harmless species? I'm from a country where death cap is fairly common and picking wild mushrooms is a national pastime (Poland). Yes, circa 10 people die from death cap poisoning each year, but there are dozens of other fungi you can't eat safely, not even after lengthy preparation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mushroom_poisoning, Polish interwiki lists them by species as present in Poland). Here the key message in media has always been "you must pick only mushrooms you are sure of". Scare campaings only lead to people destroying useful fungi in the forest out of fright.

Fungi are single celled organisms who spend most of their life cycle underground feeding on decaying organics ... once they sense they're running out of food they signal each other to migrate into clusters which push upward through the forest floor and morph into what we see as mushrooms which are their fruiting bodies (IE.  they reproduce through spores getting picked up by wind to land on more fertile grounds) ... nutrient recycling is reliant on these fungi ... to destroy them is shallow and missing the point

Excellent video! Amanitas, which account for 90% of all mushroom fatalities worldwide (although a few species are actually edible), have features in common that make them quite easy to identify as a group, once you know what these characteristics are. You'd have to be negligent or ignorant to poison yourself with one, somewhat like sticking your hand in front of a cobra.

I once led a foraging tour in Prospect Park attended by a family with a 5-year-old boy, where we repeatedly found various amanita species, so everyone knew what they looked like. 6 months later, the mom phoned me. The family had been watching a murder mystery on TV where the victim was killed by mushroom poisoning. The child cried out: "It must have been an amanita!"

Amanita phalloides and other poisonous amanita species (not all of them are poisonous) are quite common in Europe. Their poisons are harmless for many animals, mammals like deers, pigs, or rabbits, and slugs or larvea alike.

Amanita phalloides, A. verna, and A. virosa are indeed lethal but there is no need for this dramatizing sound.

When I was a medical resident at the University of Michigan in the mid-70's, a Vietnamese family was transferred in with mushroom poisoning. The kids had vomited early enough to survive, dad was dead, mom had massive liver failure and needed a transplant. At about the same time,  the head of the California Edible Wild Mushroom association also died of mushroom poisoning. That 's when I figured I'd never ever eat a wild mushroom under any circumstances. Be careful, even if you think you know what you're doing!
